hints_html: Try using physical intuition to estimate an answer. You may even be able to predict one of the coordinates precisely!
hints_latex:
Try using physical intuition to estimate an answer. You may even be able
to predict one of the coordinates precisely!
hints_raw: Try using physical intuition to estimate an answer. You may even be able to predict one of the coordinates precisely!
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
Note that we do not need to know the density, since it cancels out later. First, we calculate the area by adding the areas of the rectangle and semicircle:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A = 6 \cdot 2 + \frac{1}{2}\pi \cdot3^2 = 12+\frac{9}{2}\pi\end{aligned}\]

We identify the endpoints of the integral as \([-3,3]\), the top function as \(\sqrt{3^2-x^2}\) and the bottom function as \(-2\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{x} &= \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 x(\sqrt{3^2-x^2} + 2) \ dx \\ &= 0\end{aligned}\]

by (odd) symmetry. Alternatively, you could argue from a physical point of view that the \(x\)-coordinate of the centre of mass must be 0. By (even) symmetry,

\[\begin{aligned} \overline{y} &= \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 \frac{1}{2}[(3^2-x^2) - 2^2)] \ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{-3}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{2A}\cdot 2\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{A}\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{A}\left.\left(5x-\frac{x^3}{3}\right)\right|_0^3 \ dx \\ &= \frac{1}{A}(15-9) \\ &= \frac{6}{12+\tfrac{9}{2}\pi} \\ &= \frac{12}{24+9\pi}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Note that we do not need to know the density, since it cancels out
later. First, we calculate the area by adding the areas of the rectangle
and semicircle:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 
A = 6 \cdot 2 + \frac{1}{2}\pi \cdot3^2 = 12+\frac{9}{2}\pi
\end{align*}

We identify the endpoints of the integral as $[-3,3]$, the top function
as $\sqrt{3^2-x^2}$ and the bottom function as $-2$. Then

\begin{align*}
\overline{x} &= \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 x(\sqrt{3^2-x^2} + 2) \ dx \\
&= 0
\end{align*} by (odd) symmetry. Alternatively, you could argue from a
physical point of view that the $x$-coordinate of the centre of mass
must be 0. By (even) symmetry,

\begin{align*}
\overline{y} &= \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 \frac{1}{2}[(3^2-x^2) - 2^2)] \ dx \\
&= \frac{1}{2A}\int_{-3}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
&= \frac{1}{2A}\cdot 2\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
&= \frac{1}{A}\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
&= \frac{1}{A}\left.\left(5x-\frac{x^3}{3}\right)\right|_0^3 \ dx \\
&= \frac{1}{A}(15-9)  \\
&= \frac{6}{12+\tfrac{9}{2}\pi} \\
&= \frac{12}{24+9\pi}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Note that we do not need to know the density, since it cancels out later. First, we calculate the area by adding the areas of the rectangle and semicircle:

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
A = 6 \cdot 2 + \frac{1}{2}\pi \cdot3^2 = 12+\frac{9}{2}\pi
</math>

We identify the endpoints of the integral as <math>[-3,3]</math>, the top function as <math>\sqrt{3^2-x^2} </math> and the bottom function as <math> -2 </math>. Then 

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\overline{x} & = \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 x(\sqrt{3^2-x^2} + 2) \ dx \\
& = 0
\end{align}
</math>
by (odd) symmetry. Alternatively, you could argue from a physical point of view that the <math>x</math>-coordinate of the centre of mass must be 0. By (even) symmetry,

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\overline{y} & = \frac{1}{A} \int_{-3}^3 \frac{1}{2}[(3^2-x^2) - 2^2)] \ dx \\
& = \frac{1}{2A}\int_{-3}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
& = \frac{1}{2A}\cdot 2\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
& = \frac{1}{A}\int_{0}^3 (5-x^2) \ dx \\
& = \frac{1}{A}\left.\left(5x-\frac{x^3}{3}\right)\right|_0^3 \ dx \\
& = \frac{1}{A}(15-9)  \\
& = \frac{6}{12+\tfrac{9}{2}\pi} \\
& = \frac{12}{24+9\pi}
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:

Find the centroid of the region below, which consists of a semicircle of radius 3 on top of a rectangle of width 6 and height 2.
